I always really like how magic is portrayed in Middle earth, but most popular systems hardly are reminiscent of it.

Not that this is suprising, The nature of magic in Hobbit/LotR is semi vague and seems to draw much of its effect from meaning and authority and the literal shifting of reality and perception thats hardly ever super overt and is not spelled out like a well defined hard magic system often prefers. But it feels very natural. like its more heightening/vaguening reality in an esoteric way. A dagger that inflicts some soul disease who's blade disapears in sunlight. The power to manipulate a river to flood in the shape of a charging cavalry. The infliction of supernatural terror and hope. changing the color of pipesmoke, etched runes that only respond to a set stimuli. Its like slightly pulling back the veil of what is and isnt and heightening aspects to a certain effect, not a stark spontantiously magical thing like a magic missle or a pool of acid from not. A lot of things could almost be taken as descriptors of fine qualities rather than being obviously magic, or mirrors the semi magic/semi description of actual myths where there is a vague area between the merely exceptional or exaggerated and the actually magical (like in many instances Excalibur may be seen as just an extremely well polished and fine sword, or maybe it does shine magical light).

So are there any systems that replicate this sort of subtle magic, or do you have any ideas how to implement such a thing that gives that sort of sense in a systematized way?

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>86755984
Flight (Low Ceiling, five feet, -25%; Requires Surface, -20%; Cannot Hover, -15%) [16]. You can run along a surface at speeds between x0.5 and x2 your Basic Speed (any slower and you'll fall).

You could also add in things like Requires DX Roll (-10%) or Nuisance Effect (Must have free and functioning legs, -5%). If you need especially flat surfaces to do this (like most games that try to limit your wall running options to specific paths), add Road-Bound (-50%). If you can only wall run for so long, then add Costs FP, X/second (-X0%/level) to represent the exertion required; Maximum Duration has too many weird quirks to work well here. In any case, minimum advantage cost is [8].

If you dislike the reliance on advantages, then you could instead use the Lizard Climb cinematic skill from Martial Arts (p61). The skill has a number of modifiers to track, including the -4 you'll constantly be taking for using only your feet to "climb," so I don't think it's the simplest approach. It's also a Hard skill and requires constant rolling, so getting reliably good will not be cheap either. Which is "best" comes down to the tone you want for your game: are the PCs gigachads that can speed along most any surface with the same ease that you or I walk down a street, or are they talented but ultimately fallible individuals that still have to worry about slipping when they pull off larger-than-life stunts?

>Can I run it as a vanilla green plains...
You can in certain parts of the Iron Kingdoms. The tech-side of the setting is pretty hard-wired into the world at large. If you were to run a game set in the Protectorate (religious, low-tech, crusader types), or with one of the Hordes factions (Trollbloods and Cricle would be best candidates) then I think you could have a good game where the players raid Orgoth ruins, or disrupt Cryxian plots to attack the mainland, or something.

>Can I bar my players from picking warjack-related classes...
Yes, easily. Warjacks are very expensive and hard to maintain (worth it if you are really getting into big fights, though) and the only class that really NEEDS to interact with them are warcasters. Brawl allowed you to grapple and you can't be disarmed, unless you wear some special knuckledusters or gauntlets. Brawl - still has grapples (which are fairly OP) and technically your fists can't be disarmed.
Melee - gets +1 Evasion (you don't get +2 for a weapon in each hand) and additional +1 Evasion against grapples. Melee was always more defensive.
Archery - Best range, -3 in melee
Thrown - on hit, -1 to opponent's next action and also has -3 in melee

The general idea behind that was that a single charm could negate any difference between the weapons so you still can be flexible.

Your biggest hurdles are going to be figuring out how the communication actually happens.
Morse code never really got any notable subculture IRL because it mostly functioned as a very fast letter carrier via telegram; you hand a message off to the office and the operator transmits that to a different office which notes it down and delivers it to the recipient. This is basically just snailmail but faster and restricted to words only. Outside of the telegram office, Morse code is really only useful for communicating in scenarios where you can't speak to each other; the nature of the system means it'd be less time effecient than using a properly spoken or written language.

I imagine any sort of subculture that popped up around Morse code being used for face-to-face talking would mostly revolve around being as succinct and curt as possible. Lots of slang with contextually relevant meaning developed over years and years. Certain things are referred to by acronyms that only make sense in a language that's from two countries over, effectively becoming a new word, which becomes part of a different acronym later, which then becomes slang for something totally different.
